description:
From Middle English dissipacion, dissipacioun, from Late Latin dissipātiō.
Morphologically dissipate +‎ -ion.

entries.meaning: The act of dissipating or dispersing; a state of dispersion or separation; dispersion; waste.
A dissolute course of life, in which health, money, etc., are squandered in pursuit of pleasure; profuseness in immoral indulgence, as late hours, riotous living, etc.; dissoluteness.
examples: to reclaim the spendthrift from his dissipation and extravagance

entries.meaning: A trifle which wastes time or distracts attention.
examples: Prevented from finishing them [the letters] a thousand avocations and dissipations.

entries.meaning: (physics) A loss of energy, usually as heat, from a dynamic system.
